properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A fair weather system currently over Southwestern Quebec will continue and lead to daytime highs between 28 and 33 degrees Celsius from Wednesday to Sunday. Humidity will gradually increase beginning Thursday and lead to warmer, more uncomfortable nights. The temperatures combined with the humidity will give humidex values between 33 and 38. Although heat warning criteria will not be met, highly urbanised areas and areas in their immediate vicinity will be particularly affected. Discomfort will be particularly felt in these areas. On Saturday, areas on the St Lawrence River near Quebec City will see cooler temperatures. However, the heat and humidity will return on Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-17T12:32:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T20:33:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1756654257.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot, humid weather ahead for southern Manitoba. Temperatures will soar for today and Wednesday across southern Manitoba. A warm front pushing into the region will bring a hot, humid air mass into the province. Temperatures will climb above 30°C both days, and humidex values will reach the mid- to upper-30s as the humidity increases. Tonight, a breezy southerly wind combined with the hot and humid air mass will keep temperatures very warm through the night. In the Red River Valley and southeastern Manitoba, temperatures will likely only drop into the low twenties. A cold front will move through the province on Wednesday night, bringing a return to more seasonal temperatures and humidity. In addition to the heat, much of southern Manitoba will see the potential for thunderstorm activity over the coming days. Some of these thunderstorms will likely be severe with a variety of threats. The humid conditions will support very heavy rainfall with some thunderstorms that develop. Areas in southeastern Manitoba affected by recent heavy rains may see more torrential rainfall; on Wednesday, the region could see narrow bands of training thunderstorms resulting in significant rainfall accumulation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-17T00:56:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T08:57:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3435292981.2020

properties.Summary:

Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 34 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 3 days. An extended period of very warm to hot weather is expected. Time span: Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and possibly Saturday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 30 to 34 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 18 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over New Brunswick for the next several days. The warmest conditions are expected to occur over most areas on Thursday and Friday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-17T10:38:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T18:39:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1671097476.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Severe thunderstorms are possible across southern Saskatchewan late this afternoon and through the night as a low pressure system tracks into the region from Montana. ### Fast-moving water across a road can sweep a vehicle away. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-17T11:21:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T21:23:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0298029772.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:45 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. A severe thunderstorm is tracking across Lake Manitoba toward the Clarkleigh area. This thunderstorm is moving to the east-northeast at 70 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Fast-moving water across a road can sweep a vehicle away. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-16T22:44:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T19:46:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2935945144.2020
Area: R.M. of Coldwell incl. Lundar and Clarkleigh, R.M. of West Interlake incl. Eriksdale and Ashern

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots, frequent lightning, hail up to 2 centimetres and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times are expected or occurring in the area. A severe thunderstorm capable of producing hail and wind gusts in excess of 34 kts is tracking across Lake Manitoba from west to east, from near Amaranth toward Clarkleigh. ### Proceed with caution as visibility may suddenly be reduced to near zero. Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-06-16T22:38:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T19:40:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0574827750.2020
Area: Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:15 p.m. CST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a dangerous thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to golf ball size hail and heavy rain. This thunderstorm is 10 km north of Cupar and is moving northeast at 60 km/h. Golf ball sized hail was reported in Southey. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-17T00:54:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T22:16:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0841616118.2020
Area: R.M. of Cupar including Southey Cupar and Markinch, R.M. of Lipton including Lipton and Dysart, R.M. of Touchwood including Serath and Touchwood Hills Prov. Park, R.M. of Kellross including Kelliher and Lestock
